title: What the hell is the point of Abyssal Voyage's on hit extra damage
body:
Makes no sense to randomly attach it to his ultimate, what part of "I eat team mate and we shoot across the map" equates to % of Tahm's max health as extra on hit damage

It just feels like you had another passive in mind for him but didn't want to give him 2 upfront passives, so you tacked it onto his ult

Why so damn overloaded?

replies.body:
We gave Tahm Kench bonus damage on his auto attacks because without it he lacked enough of an impact in fights. That's an issue that champions with non combat abilities, such as Tahm's ult, are at risk of. 

The passive's on his ult specifically so that he follows a similar power curve to other champions, with a significant power spike at level 6 in particular. Putting some, or all, of the on hit damage on his character passive instead resulted in a champion that bullied others hard in the really levels and/or got crushed once other champions hit 6. It's not a good thematic fit for the active part of the ult, but in this case we felt the needs of gameplay needed to trump going for a stronger thematic fit.

As far as overload goes I'd agree we've had some champions in the past year with a bit much on their kits. I'd disagree that Tahm Kench is one of them though, the number of discrete effects he's got going on is pretty trackable, doesn't diffuse power/satisfaction too much and gives a fairly broad set of levers to adjust him f needed.
Are there any plans on a similar aproach for Twosted Fate and Shen, as both have a no-combat Ult aswell?

Shen and TF have somewhat different solutions. Shen ult grants a substantial shield to give it in combat impact, rather than just into combat power. TF by contrast has extra power loaded into his W in particular (there's a lot more power there than the average basic ability).

well, Shen still has a little powercurve problem in toplane, which is probably one of the reasons why he sees more success as support.
Shen usually can dominate most matchups till level 6 due his strong 1v1 base kit, and from there on he usually has troubles and relys on makeing plays with his global as other toplaners just get a massive combat spike that he doesn't have at 6 in a 1v1( though disableing yourself for that shiled is usually not great in a 2v2 aswell, might save a life, but wont win a fight)


Tf is in a bit different place, he also lacks raw combatpower at 6 somcompared to other midlaners and should make up for it with his global presure, but unlike shen he has great ranged waveclear, so he can easily avoid combat with the laneopponent without loosing cs, so lacking raw combat power doesn't really hurt him to much i guess

Shen can be a decent damage threat on his own just from his bases, and has the potential to really disrupt the enemy team with a good taunt. And the massive shield on his ult can turn around a fight on its own.

Tahm is an immobile tank who has to stay in the fight for extended periods of time. If he gets kited to where he can't land 3 stacks, he deserves to at least be able to deal a little damage to the front line.

Otherwise you just end up with someone like Alistar who throws out his abilities hoping he hits someone and just kind of stands there waiting for CDs the rest of the fight.

So was Tahm made to be a support or a top laner? The last time you (Riot) made a support with the idea he could be a top laner, we had a champion with such a powerful kit (Thresh) that he's always been supper strong. Not to mention the other supports that were given the ability to solo lane (Lulu, old Soraka, ect...) either are bad as support (Lulu) or needed an overhaul (Soraka).

We originally intended Tahm to be a tank, rather than a support. As his kit developed however we found that it was taking on some support like qualities. We concluded we liked those, so embraced them rather than trying to shift him back to the initial goal we had.

In terms of where Tahm plays on the other hand that's something we hope's flexible. We have had to adjust some supports that have solo laned and been really unhealthy there (e.g. Janna clearing entire waves mid with one spell from her own tower). We do think there's a lot of value in the variety healthy supports, or supportish champs, offer in other positions than bot though (e.g. Nunu jungle or Morg mid).

I don't really feel that Nunu is a support being played in the jungle so much as he's a jungler being played as a support. Devour would not exist on his kit if he was meant to be a jungler, at least not the bonuses for eating jungle minions.

Nunu's definitely designed to be at home in the jungle, with you there. This sort of conversation can get a little bit murky though since 'support' is used to describe both a class (champion whose power amplifies others, has high base utility/low scaling, isn't damage focused etc) and a position (non farming champion, most often found in a duo lane bot). The support class is most often played in the support position, there are some exceptions though, and Nunu's one I'd call out as a support who generally works best in the jungle. We also see a larger range of champions in the support position than just those from the support class. Lot of mages are strong picks as non CSing duo laners (Annie, Zyra, Fiddlesticks etc), as are a number of tanks (Braum, Alistar etc) and occasionally champions from other classes (the odd Le Blanc or Yorick support for example).

But Nunu was made as a jungler right? He got nerfed after being a strong support. And Morg was nerfed as a midlaner and pushed to support right? Elise got nerfed after being a strong support, same with Zyra. I could be wrong on some of these. But champs that are set as "jungle" or "solo lane" always seem to get changed if they bleed into another role. I don't wish to sound mean, but the track record on multi role champs is not very strong. (ignore a mid/top/adc that can tend to rotate, it's mostly jungle and supports that have the issue)

She was a top tier midlane for a while. Old Dignatas used her mid and Lulu top at one point. So she got nerfed until they could rebuild her to a more "pure" support.
She did indeed see play mid. (And top if I remember correctly), but she was always _intended_ to be a pure support...
But that's my point. She was too good at multiple roles so they remade her. Junglers & Support don't seem to be very easy to balance if they play another role.

Please, someone, explain to me, what is the problem with having two or three passives on a champion? Since when is having multiple passives overloaded?

The entire point of this second passive is to give Tahm power scaling. It's specifically attached to his ultimate, so that he doesn't have this bonus at the start of the game. It's like Sivir's ult passive; not directly attached to her W, so that her power curve is more controlled.
